The human <extra_id_0> interleukin-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) gene is expressed almost exclusively in activated T cells .

text: We have previously shown that treatment of Jurkat T cells with <extra_id_0> phytohemaglutinin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and the phorbol ester , PMA , activated transcription initiation from the <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

text: To define the regions of the gene required for transcription activation , we generated a series of reporter constructs containing different regions of the <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene 5 ' and 3 ' flanking sequences .
Both positive and negative regulatory elements were identified in the proximal 5 ' flanking region of the <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .
The promoter region between -173 and -60 contained the strongest activating elements .
The transcription factor AP-1 could bind to this positive activator region of the promoter .

We also examined the function of the <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> CK-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> CK-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> elements that are present in many cytokine genes and found that they acted as a repressor of basal level expression when cloned upstream of a heterologous promoter but were also inducible by PMA / <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
